conclusion: Apply Snell’s law at entry point A (vacuum → material): n sin θ₂ = sin 45° where θ₂ is the angle the refracted ray makes with the normal inside the material.
Inside the shell the ray must just graze the inner spherical surface of radius R before emerging.
“Grazing” means the refracted ray is tangent to the inner sphere, so its perpendicular distance from the centre equals R.

Geometry of the annulus (outer radius 2R, inner radius R) shows that the ray which enters at the outer surface and travels a straight line making angle θ₂ with the normal will be tangent to the inner sphere when sin θ₂ = ½.
From sin θ₂ = ½ and Snell’s law (step 1): n (½) = sin 45° = 1/√2 ⇒ n = (1/√2)/(½) = √2.
The refractive index of the transparent material is √2 ≃ 1.414.
